notes.title: Vector Calculus: ∇, grad, div, curl, Laplacian & Identities
notes.content: Master definitions (in Cartesian & curvilinear coordinates), physical meaning (e.g., div = source density, curl = local rotation), and identity proofs used in EM and fluid derivations. Be ready to compute line/surface/volume integrals and use vector triple product identities.
keyTakeaways: Memorize and practice key vector identities (product rules, ∇·(∇×A)=0, ∇×(∇ϕ)=0, ∇²ϕ=∇·∇ϕ).
Geometric/physical interpretations often earn method marks even if arithmetic slips.
Directly connects to Maxwell's equations, Poynting theorem, Laplacian in Poisson/Helmholtz.

resources.title: Paul's Online Math Notes — Curl & Divergence
MIT OCW 18.02 — Multivariable Calculus (notes)
resources.description: Lecture notes covering grad/div/curl & integral theorems

notes.title: Maxwell's Equations, Potentials & Poynting Theorem
notes.content: Know differential & integral forms, boundary conditions, wave equation in free space, and energy/momentum flow of EM fields via Poynting vector. Be prepared to derive Poynting theorem and compute energy density/intensity.
keyTakeaways: From Faraday + Ampère–Maxwell ⇒ wave equations c=1/√(μ0ε0).
Poynting vector S = (1/μ0) E×B; ⟨S⟩ governs intensity.
Vector/scalar potentials (A, ϕ) with gauges simplify problems.

resources.title: Feynman Lectures Vol. II — Ch. 27 Field Energy & Momentum
resources.description: Beautiful derivation & intuition for Poynting vector

resources.title: OpenStax Univ. Physics Vol. 2 — Energy in EM Waves
resources.description: Worked examples on ⟨S⟩ and energy density

notes.title: Electrostatics & Magnetostatics Problem-Solving
notes.content: Gauss's law applications (planar, cylindrical, spherical), potentials/field from charge distributions; Biot–Savart & Ampère for B-fields; capacitor energy density; dipole fields & torque.
keyTakeaways: Choose symmetry + Gaussian/Amperian surfaces wisely.
Relate E to V via gradients; use superposition & images where allowed.
Energy density in dielectrics and boundary conditions are frequent MCQs.

resources.title: OpenStax Vol. 2 — Gauss's Law to Capacitors (Ch. 6–8)
MIT OCW 8.02 — Lecture Notes Index
resources.description: Gauss, Ampère, displacement current & Poynting problem sets

resources.title: Feynman Lectures Vol. II — Vector Field Calculus

notes.title: AC Circuits, RLC, Transformers & Rectifiers
notes.content: Phasor/impedance methods for RLC (series/parallel), resonance & Q, power factor; transformer basics; rectification & filter smoothing; common MCQ traps.
keyTakeaways: Memorize Z_R=R, Z_L=jωL, Z_C=1/(jωC) and resonance ω0=1/√(LC).
Know quality factor, bandwidth, and power in AC.
PN junction rectifiers: half/full-wave behavior & ripple.

resources.title: All About Circuits — Textbook (AC, RLC, Power)

notes.title: Waves & Optics: Interference, Diffraction, Polarization, Lasers
notes.content: Young's double slit, single/multiple-slit diffraction, Rayleigh criterion, thin-film colors, coherence; standing vs traveling waves; phase & group velocity; lasers & safety.
keyTakeaways: Fringe formulas: Δy=λL/d, sinθ_m=mλ/a, resolving power ~ mN for gratings.
Thin films: path & phase shifts (π on reflection from higher n).
Standing waves carry no net energy; nodes/antinodes conditions are examinable.

resources.title: OpenStax Vol. 3 — Wave Optics (Young's Double Slit)
MIT Jr. Lab — Michelson Interferometer Lab Guide (PDF)

notes.title: Mechanics & Dynamics: Work–Energy, SHM, Kepler & Orbits
notes.content: Work–energy theorem, central forces & angular momentum conservation, SHM derivations and energy graphs, projectile/circular motion, Kepler's laws and satellite periods.
keyTakeaways: Always start from definitions: W=∫F·dr; in rotation, τ=dL/dt and K_rot=½Iω².
SHM links: a=−ω²x, energy swap between KE & PE; drawing helps.
Kepler T²∝a³; exploit vis-viva equation for orbit speed/period changes.

notes.title: Rotational Dynamics: I, Parallel-Axis, Rigid-Body Energy
notes.content: Compute I for rods/discs/spheres; derive parallel-axis; connect translational & rotational energy and angular momentum conservation; common exam numericals.
keyTakeaways: Parallel-axis: I = I_cm + Md²; memorize standard I tables.
Rolling without slipping constraints save time.
Torque vs time to get ω(t) and θ(t) under constant τ.

resources.title: MIT OCW 8.01 — Rotation modules
resources.description: Worked problems on I and τ

notes.title: Thermodynamics & Statistical Mechanics: Laws, Carnot, Entropy
notes.content: Statements of 0th–3rd laws; reversible/irreversible processes; Carnot efficiency and proofs; entropy changes; ideal vs real gases (van der Waals); basic stat-mech ideas.
keyTakeaways: Carnot efficiency η=1−Tc/Th; connect Clausius/Kelvin–Planck equivalence.
For reversible processes dS=δQ_rev/T; irreversible ⇒ ΔS_total>0.
Van der Waals corrects P and volume for real gases; be ready for numericals.

resources.title: OpenStax Vol. 2 — The Second Law & Carnot (Ch. 4.5–4.6)

notes.title: Modern Physics & Quantum: Schrödinger, Operators, Wells
notes.content: Time-dependent/independent Schrödinger equations, boundary problems (infinite/finite wells), expectation values & uncertainties, de Broglie & photoelectric effect, quantum numbers.
keyTakeaways: Be fluent with normalization, ⟨x⟩, ⟨p⟩, ⟨H⟩; use operator algebra and commutators.
Particle in a box energies ∝ n²; sketch eigenfunctions & |ψ|².
Photoelectric: KE_max = hf − φ; threshold freq questions are common.

resources.title: MIT OCW 8.04 — Quantum Physics I (full OCW site)

notes.title: Special Relativity: Time Dilation, Length Contraction, Energy–Momentum
notes.content: Postulates, Lorentz transformations, velocity addition, E² = p²c² + m²c⁴, mass–energy equivalence; exam numericals with muons/clocks & spacecraft speeds.
keyTakeaways: Keep γ=1/√(1−v²/c²) at fingertips; practice unit consistency.
E–p relation derivation and limiting cases (photon vs massive).
Compare Galilean vs relativistic addition in MCQs.

resources.title: OpenStax Vol. 3 — Relativity (SR)
resources.description: Worked problems on γ, Δt, ΔL

notes.title: Fluid Dynamics: Bernoulli, Continuity & Applications
notes.content: Derive Bernoulli from energy conservation for incompressible, inviscid flow; apply to Venturi tubes, lift on airfoils, pipe constrictions; continuity equation usage.
keyTakeaways: Identify when assumptions hold; add viscosity/head loss only if stated.
Combine Bernoulli with continuity A1v1=A2v2 for speed/pressure.
Dimension checks prevent algebra slips.

notes.title: Nuclear Physics & Radiation Detection; Solid State & Semiconductors
notes.content: Nuclear models (liquid drop, shell), fission/fusion, Q-value & half-life; reactors & detectors (GM, scintillation). For solids: band theory, intrinsic/extrinsic, PN junctions, diodes/transistors, MOSFET basics.
keyTakeaways: Half-life/mean-life formulae are routine MCQs; always show log steps.
Reactor parts: moderator, control rods, coolant, shielding.
Semiconductor band diagrams + biasing explain rectification and device behavior.

resources.title: MIT OCW 3.091 — Band Theory & Semiconductors
resources.description: Lectures on band theory and semiconductors
